entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 19th March 2023 - 4th Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 19th March 2023 - 4th Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
Call to worship Leader: Let us worship the Living God, Women: who is mother Men: and father, Women: loving saviour Men: and faithful friend, Leader: alpha and omega, All: the beginning and the end, Leader: life and being beyond all we can imagine. All: We come to worship our God.
HYMN R&S 74 Praise to the Lord
Introduction: How do you pray? How do you see, imagine or name the immortal, invisible God?
1 st Reading: Psalm 131 (The Message) read by Jeany Bien GOD, I’m not trying to rule the roost, I don’t want to be king of the mountain. I haven’t meddled where I have no business or fantasized grandiose plans. 2 I’ve kept my feet on the ground, I’ve cultivated a quiet heart.
Like a baby content in its mother’s arms, my soul is a baby content. 3 Wait, Israel, for GOD. Wait with hope. Hope now; hope always!
Prayer
SONG MP 1076 Jesus be the centre
2nd Reading Luke 13.34 read by Kitty Bird Jesus said, ‘Jerusalem…How often have I desired to gather your children together as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you were not willing!’
Short talk: ‘Mothering – instinct to protect’
SONG MP 583 Safe in the shadow of the Lord
3 rd reading Matthew 12.46-50 NIVUK read by Kitty Bird 46 While Jesus was still talking to the crowd, his mother and brothers stood outside, wanting to speak to him. 47 Someone told him, ‘Your mother and brothers are standing outside, wanting to speak to you.’ 48 He replied, ‘Who is my mother, and who are my brothers?’ 49 Pointing to his disciples, he said, ‘Here are my mother and my brothers. 50 For whoever does the will of my Father in heaven is my brother and sister and mother.’ 4 th Reading: John 19.26-27 read by Jeany Bien 26 When Jesus saw his mother there, and the disciple whom he loved standing near by, he said to her, ‘Woman, here is your son,’ 27 and to the disciple, ‘Here is your mother.’ From that time on, this disciple took her into his home.
Short Talk: ‘God’s new family’
HYMN R&S 41 For the beauty of the earth (Tune: 575)
All age Activity: ‘connected as one family’
HYMN R&S 518 Father I place into your hands
Leader: God who is father and mother to us all, All: We place them in your hands.
Lord’s Prayer (modern version)
HYMN R&S 531 Lord of all hopefulness
Blessing
Music, photos , and notices after the service

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 12th March 2023 - 3rd Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 12th March 2023 - 3rd Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
05:05 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
05:23 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle led by Linda Curley
06:33 - Call to worship led by Linda Curley We come to God rejoicing: We bring our thanks and praise. We come to God with our needs and concerns: We bring our hopes and prayers.
06:51 - 11:07 - Hymn R&S 39 All creatures of our God and King (vs 1-4 only)
11:39 - 12:59 - Reading: Psalm 95. 1 – 7 (adapted) read by Abigail Lokko
13:18 - 14:48 - Introduction to the theme: ‘water of life’ Reading: John 4. 5 – 8 NIVUK read by Rosemary Taylor
14:50 - 16:39 - Prayer Lord's Prayer
16:48 - 19:25 - Song MP God forgave my sin in Jesus’ name
19:53 - 26:26 - Talk for all ages: ‘Wells, water and well-being’ The story of Jesus meeting a Samaritan at a well and the importance of water in our lives. Water has been treated with great respect throughout history and is often seen as a holy place linked to particular local saints with healing miracles. A church in Bierton, North of Aylesbury, linked to a Christian woman from medieval times called Asif. Rivers, especially chalk streams, are important for wildlife and need to be looked after for the benefit of both wildlife and ourselves. Sewage is sometimes dumped into our rivers, which is surely a disgrace to our nation. The psalm used in the service reminds us that the planet belongs to God and the oceans belong to God, their maker. A new high seas treaty by the United Nations to create large protected areas of the oceans to safeguard marine biodiversity. Water is a key theme in Lent this year with support for Water Aid, which provides clean water and sanitation to many poor communities around the world. The effects of climate change on water supplies in many poorer nations and the need to create water and sanitation services that last and can come back quickly online after a climate hazard. Women's voices and experiences are essential in adapting to climate change, and they must be heard and acted upon.
26:35 - 29:01 - Hymn R&S 572 Colours of day
29:17 - 31:03 - Reading: John 4.6 - 15 read by Norma Garden
31:18 - 34:20 - Hymn R&S 349 I heard the voice
34:50 - 37:50 - Reading: John 4.16 – 30 NIVUK read by Abigail Lokko
38:19 - 44:11- Short Address Wells are significant places in the Bible, and many important meetings took place at wells. Jacob's Well, located in modern-day Palestine, is the most famous well in the Bible. Maria, who lives in a small island in El Salvador, has to travel to the mainland every day to fetch water because there is no mains water on her island. Many women in low-income countries have to do this kind of work every day. In the encounter between Jesus and the Samaritan woman, both were thirsty and had to act to quench their thirst. The physical and spiritual aspects of our lives are intertwined and essential to our well-being. The American theologian Sally McFague believed that the interconnection of our souls and bodies brings us life in all its fullness. We should value both physical and spiritual water as essential to our life and well-being. We should recognize and accept everyone as brother and sister, as well as being accepted as a child of God. We should be thirsty for the Water of Life.
followed by 2 or 3 minutes of quiet reflection on these questions: - Do we welcome and value both the physical water and the spiritual water as essential to our life and well-being? - What do they teach us about recognising and accepting everyone as brother and sister? - What do we learn for ourselves about being accepted as brother or sister, and a child of God? - Are we thirsty for the water of life?
44:29 - 46:35 - Hymn R&S 543 Lead us heavenly Father lead us
46:45 - 48:42 - Reading: John 4.31 – 42 NIVUK read by Norma Garden
49:11 - 54:02 - Prayers for the world led by Sue Thorne
54:12 - 57:46 - Hymn R&S 579 Lord thy Church on earth
57:48 - 58:18 - Blessing
58:52 - 01:01:40 - Music, photos , and notices after the service
#Church #Worship #Sing #Organ #Faithful #Jesus #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Blessings #GoodNews #NIV #NIVUK #Bible #Lessons #King #GoodNews #Hymns #AllAreWelcome #JoinIn #Christian #WarmSpace #WednesdayCafe #RejoiceandSing #Compassion #Lent #PrayersForTurkey #Temptation #Armor #Nicodemus #TheRepairShop #RepairShop #GBSnowSport #ParaSnowsport #SummarisedWithChatGPT #Aylesbury #Bierton #Water #ClimateChange #Sewage #WaterAid #SomeHose #TwoRonnies

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 5th March 2023 - 2nd Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 5th March 2023 - 2nd Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
Worship and Communion led by Terry Hinks Organist: Andrew Winton
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
07:55 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
10:13 - Call to worship We come to worship you, Lord, the maker of our lives. We come to meet you, Lord, the keeper of our lives. We come to hear you, Lord, the wisdom in our lives. We come to follow you, Lord, the guider of our lives.
11:06 - 13:36 - Hymn - R&S 67 Immortal, invisible, God only wise
13:42 - Prayers of adoration and confession
15:30 - 28:51 - All age talk: ‘Help! I need somebody!’ The Beatles and their song "Help" as an example of asking for help. What helps you get through the day - things like daily devotions, friends, family, and nature. The importance of turning to God for help, as well as offering help to others. The Jars of Change appeal, which involves setting aside money over Lent to donate to the charity. The charity's focus this year is on providing clean water and sanitation to communities in need. Stories of two young women who have benefited from the charity's work. The idea of giving and helping others, even in small ways. A reminder that help can come from God and from our willingness to offer help to others.
29:18 - 30:16 - Reading: Psalm 121 NIVUK read by Ian Bogart I lift up my eyes to the mountains – where does my help come from? 2 My help comes from the Lord, the Maker of heaven and earth. 3 He will not let your foot slip – he who watches over you will not slumber; 4 indeed, he who watches over Israel will neither slumber nor sleep. 5 The Lord watches over you – the Lord is your shade at your right hand; 6 the sun will not harm you by day, nor the moon by night. 7 The Lord will keep you from all harm – he will watch over your life; 8 the Lord will watch over your coming and going both now and for evermore.
31:00 - 33:37 - Hymn - R&S 64 I lift my eyes to the quiet hills
33:44 - Introduction to the reading
34:47 - 37:13 - Reading: John 3.1-17 NIVUK
37:34 - 39:39 - Hymn - MP 619 Such love
39:43 - 53:26 - Short Address: The Repair Shop and the team of experts who restore old and broken items. In August 2021, the team met with Prince Charles and learned about his foundation's work in training young craftspeople. Charles gave the team a piece of pottery made for Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee and an 18th-century clock to repair. Jay Blades, one of the show's hosts, grew up in Hackney, and he and Charles bonded over their shared interests in apprenticeships and heritage crafts. The encounter between Nicodemus and Jesus in the Bible is similar to the meeting of Blades and Charles in that it brings together people from different backgrounds who share common interests. Nicodemus is a Pharisee and a member of the ruling council in Jerusalem who comes to meet Jesus at night. Nicodemus recognizes that God is at work in Jesus's ministry and life. Jesus tells Nicodemus that he must be born again to see the kingdom of God. This spiritual rebirth is about a fundamental change that enables us to see the kingdom of love, justice, and peace where God is at the center. Jesus teaches that his followers must become like little children to enter the kingdom of heaven. The kingdom of heaven is a place where God is at the center and all are of equal worth in the eyes of God.
53:30 - 58:22 - Prayers for the world with the response So, God of compassion: open our hearts, to welcome all.
58:23 - Prayer of Dedication of all our gifts
01:01:41 - Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ. A Prayer of thanksgiving and Lord’s Prayer
Distribution of bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice)
Closing Prayer
01:08:27 - 01:11:02 - Hymn R&S 345 Guide me O thou Great Jehovah
01:11:03 - 01:11:32 - Blessing
01:11:58 - 01:15:16 - Music, photos , and notices after the service
#Church #Worship #Sing #Organ #Faithful #Jesus #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Blessings #GoodNews #NIV #NIVUK #Bible #Lessons #King #GoodNews #Hymns #AllAreWelcome #JoinIn #Christian #WarmSpace #WednesdayCafe #RejoiceandSing #Compassion #Lent #PrayersForTurkey #Temptation #Armor #Nicodemus #TheRepairShop #RepairShop

entry.title: Morning Worship - Sunday 26th February 2023 - 1st Sunday In Lent

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 26th February 2023 - 1st Sunday In Lent
media:group.media:description:
Worship led by Richard Goldstraw Organist: Charles Brewster
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
02:26 - Welcome and lighting of the peace candle
04:29 - Call to worship
05:27 - 09:30 - Hymn – Praise to the holiest – Tune Gerontius
09:38 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
12:30 - 15:35 - Talk for all ages The meaning and history of Lent, a season of penitence and self-denial observed to prepare for the Easter celebration. The importance of prayer, self-examination, and repentance during this period, as well as reading and meditating on God's word. A creative Lent daily program, which includes different activities for each day of the week Sunday: Social media fast Monday: Keep silence for at least 10 minutes Tuesday: Do a prayer walk around your neighborhood Wednesday: Fast your way (in a manner that is appropriate for your personal circumstances and needs) Thursday: Connect with a friend by calling, texting, or sending an email Friday: Read and reflect on God's holy word Saturday: Rest and refresh. Lent is our opportunity to grow in faith and devotion to Christ.
16:26 - 20:58 - Hymn – Dear Lord and Father
22:02 - Introduction to Bible readings
22:35 - 24:18 - Readings: Psalm 32 NIVUK
24:40 - 26:11 - Matthew 4:1-11
27:29 - 29:42 - Hymn R&S 543– Lead us heavenly Father Lead Us
29:48 - 41:05 - Sermon followed by time of quiet reflection Drawing inspiration from the hymn "Father Lead Me Day by Day" and Jesus' identity affirmation from God during his baptism. The assurance of being saved by grace is necessary in our lives. The promises of God should be hidden in our hearts to remain steadfast during temptations. The full armor of God should be worn to stand firm against the devil's schemes. Jesus defeated Satan on the cross, and we must use his name to resist temptations. Jesus' response to temptations was quoting the word of God. The spirit drives us into unusual and unexplored places. The spirit is at work whenever people speak the language of love, dream of a new community, and reach out to one another. God is gracious and picks us up when we stumble and fall into ditches along the way. Nothing in all creation can separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus, and goodness is stronger than evil, love is stronger than hate. As children of God, we need to have the promises of God hidden in our hearts and be sure of our identity in Him. Temptations will come, but we can stand firm by putting on the full armor of God and using the Word of God to resist the devil's schemes. The Spirit may also drive us into unusual and unexplored places, and we need to be open to following His leading. Ultimately, we can take comfort in the fact that nothing can separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus, and victory is ours through Him who loves us.
42:45 - 44:28 - Hymn – In my life Lord, Be Glorified
44:33 - 50:09 - Prayers for others and ourselves
51:59 - 55:40 - Hymn– O Jesus I have promised – Tune Hatherop
56:19 - 56:40 - Closing blessing
57:01 - 01:02:24 - Music, photos , and notices after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 19th February 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
08:00 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
08:20 - Welcome and lighting of the peace candle
10:28 - Call to worship Exalt the Lord our God and worship at his holy mountain, for the Lord our God is holy. Grace and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ
10:56 - 14:37 - Hymn - MP 77 Christ triumphant
14:40 - Opening Prayer of praise with the response God of glory (truth), to you We offer our worship and praise.
17:35 - Lord’s Prayer (modern version)
18:18 - Introduction: ‘what just happened?’ The importance of paying attention and being good witnesses in our daily lives. A scene from Sherlock Holmes to illustrate how we often do things without noticing.
25:43 - 27:09 - Readings: Exodus 24.12-18 NIVUK
27:23 - 36:34 - Short Talk: ‘A mountain top experience’ The story of Moses and the giving of the Ten Commandments is a significant moment in the faith story. The invitation from God for Moses to come up the mountain was initially frightening but is seen as gracious. Mountains have been sacred places in many different cultures and faiths, and they speak of powers beyond our own. The Holy God is described as a mystery, appearing as cloud, blazing light, and fire. The law that Moses was given on the mountain would make the Israelites a holy people as they live by the Commandments of honoring God and loving their neighbor. Moses stayed on the mountain for 40 days and 40 nights, which is significant in both the Old and New Testaments. Lent is a period of 40 days, leading up to the eve of Easter, and represents a journey towards the Mountaintop of Easter day. The signs of spring, such as snowdrops, are a symbol of God's renewing love and a reminder of the presence of Jesus. The prayer at the end of the passage is a reminder to seek hope and peace during the darker days and to be enlightened on our journey through Lent and beyond.
36:44 - 40:03 - Hymn - 454 Majesty, worship his majesty
40:32 - 41:57 - Reading: Matthew 17. 1 – 9 (The Message)
42:36 - 44:22 - Hymn - MP 545 Open our eyes Lord (sung twice seated)
45:20 - 47:13 - Reflection: ‘After the event’ Peter, James and John remember "Brothers of thunder"
48:18 - 51:19 - Hymn - MP 1227 The splendour of the King
51:22 - 01:00:35 - Short talk: ‘wonderers, worshippers and witnesses’ The topic of reflection is the story of the three disciples who went up the mountain with Jesus and witnessed the splendor of God. A reflection on four words related to the story of Jesus and his disciples on the mountain: wonder, worship, witness, and work. Wonder: Take a step back and wonder at the mysteries of God's presence, creation, and scripture during the season of Lent. Worship: The disciples' worship involved listening to Jesus, listen deeply to Jesus in scripture as the heart of worship. Witness: Witness to the reality of Jesus with humility and through both words and actions. Work: The disciples were invited to be part of the work of Jesus, we should pray for and participate in God's work in the world today.
The disciples' experience on the mountain was a revelation of divine light that they could not put into words. The disciples' response was to worship, but they had a lot to learn about true worship, which involves following and listening to Jesus. Listening to Jesus is at the heart of worship and is an essential aspect of our tradition. After wandering, worshiping, and listening, we are called to be witnesses of Jesus, but our witness can be mistaken if we fail to witness to the reality of Jesus. Witnessing requires humility and a deep understanding of the love of God. We are encouraged to pray for God's work in the world and for our part in it.
Prayer Activity ending with shared prayer
All our prayers, silent and spoken we bring to you, God of life and light. Help us to know the love of Jesus, to see his hidden glory, shining all around. Amen.
01:00:47 - 01:04:24 - Hymn - MP 728 We have a gospel to proclaim
01:04:26 - 01:04:48 - Blessing
01:05:13 - 01:10:30 - Music, notices and photos
Summarised with #ChatGPT
#Church #Worship #Sing #Organ #Faithful #Jesus #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Blessings #GoodNews #NIV #NIVUK #Bible #Lessons #King #GoodNews #Hymns #AllAreWelcome #JoinIn #Christian #WarmSpace #WednesdayCafe #RejoiceandSing #Compassion #Lent #PrayersForTurkey

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 12th February 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
10:07 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
12:08 - Call to worship
13:07 - 15:38 - Hymn R&S 97: King of glory, King of peace
15:41 - Opening Prayers 18:11 - Lord’s Prayer
19:06 - Reading: Matthew 6. 25 – 34 NIVUK read by Sue Thorne 25 ‘Therefore I tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or drink; or about your body, what you will wear. Is not life more than food, and the body more than clothes? 26 Look at the birds of the air; they do not sow or reap or store away in barns, and yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not much more valuable than they? 27 Can any one of you by worrying add a single hour to your life [ ? 28 ‘And why do you worry about clothes? See how the flowers of the field grow. They do not labour or spin. 29 Yet I tell you that not even Solomon in all his splendour was dressed like one of these. 30 If that is how God clothes the grass of the field, which is here today and tomorrow is thrown into the fire, will he not much more clothe you – you of little faith? 31 So do not worry, saying, “What shall we eat?” or “What shall we drink?” or “What shall we wear?” 32 For the pagans run after all these things, and your heavenly Father knows that you need them. 33 But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well. 34 Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about itself. Each day has enough trouble of its own.
20:56 - 25:03 - Introduction to the service (all age talk) Worrying is a common experience that is not always easy to overcome. We often worry about trivial things that waste our time and energy. Jesus wanted people to be free of constant worrying. Worrying about a job change and how it turned out to be unnecessary. Jesus advises us to put our worries down and not let them make our lives hard. Life will have its ups and downs, and worrying only makes it worse. Trusting in God and his love can help us cope with life's challenges. We should focus on living one day at a time instead of worrying about the future. God will bring us safely through life's difficulties and to heaven. Trust in God's love and rely on Him to help us cope with life's challenges instead of worrying about things that are outside of our control.
25:19 - 28:44 - Hymn R&S 86: God who stretched the spangled heavens
29:10 - 31:10 - Reading: Romans 8. 18 – 25 NIVUK read by John Hillson (seated) 18 I consider that our present sufferings are not worth comparing with the glory that will be revealed in us. 19 For the creation waits in eager expectation for the children of God to be revealed. 20 For the creation was subjected to frustration, not by its own choice, but by the will of the one who subjected it, in hope 21 that [a] the creation itself will be liberated from its bondage to decay and brought into the freedom and glory of the children of God. 22 We know that the whole creation has been groaning as in the pains of childbirth right up to the present time. 23 Not only so, but we ourselves, who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, groan inwardly as we wait eagerly for our adoption to sonship, the redemption of our bodies. 24 For in this hope we were saved. But hope that is seen is no hope at all. Who hopes for what they already have? 25 But if we hope for what we do not yet have, we wait for it patiently.
31:25 - 34:50 - Hymn R&S 364: Just as I am
34:57 - 49:43 - Address Our age is characterized by anxiety and worry. Hyper-connectivity in a globalized world increases our exposure to anxiety and worry. Some people are more prone to anxiety than others. God will take care of what comes our way in life. Life is more important than material possessions. Focusing on the present moment and giving attention to what God is doing can alleviate worry and anxiety. Worry is illogical and misses the point of life. Trusting God and living one day at a time is the way to true peace. As Christians, we're called to have faith in God's care and provision. Worry and anxiety are incompatible with this faith. Trust that God knows your every need, not just your wants. Live each day with gratitude and reliance on Him. Today is the only performance we'll give. Let's make the most of it by trusting God, living with purpose, and rejoicing in His goodness. #faith #trustGod #dontworry #liveonedayatatime #rejoice
50:12 - 53:52 - Hymn R&S 267: Immortal love for ever full
53:56 - Prayers of intercession
58:55 - 01:02:16 - Hymn R&S 285: O for a thousand tongues to sing
01:02:18 - 01:02:39 - Blessing
01:03:07 - 01:07:00 - Music, notices and photos
#Church #Worship #Sing #Organ #Faithful #Jesus #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Blessings #GoodNews #NIV #NIVUK #Bible #Lessons #King #GoodNews #Hymns #AllAreWelcome #JoinIn #Christian #WarmSpace #WednesdayCafe #RejoiceandSing #Compassion #Lent #PrayersForTurkey

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 29th January 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
07:50 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
09:22 - Call to worship Let us come into the presence of God… …so together we come to worship We come to worship the Living God Together we come to be still and know We come to know that we are loved by God, the source of all life and truth and love. Amen
10:19 - 14:32 - Hymn - MP 1259 Bless the Lord my soul (Matt Redman)
14:38 - Prayers of adoration and confession
Lord's Prayer
16:46 - 27:50 - All age talk: Well I’m blessed!’ and ‘Bless you!’ Use of the word "bless" and its variations in the context of Christianity and worship. Counting one's blessings and giving thanks to God, even on difficult days. Photographs sent in by members of the congregation during worship. Sharing our own blessings Linking to the Beatitudes The importance of blessings in the Christian life and the act of giving thanks to God. The joy of having a good pudding as a blessing and enjoying a good apple crumble.
27:53 - 28:58 - Reading: Psalm 15 (The Message)
29:27 - 33:00 - Hymn - TP 15 Bind us together
33:36 - Introduction to the readings
34:35 - 36:40 - Reading: Micah 6.1 – 8 NIVUK read by Alan Yates He has shown you, O mortal, what is good. And what does the LORD require of you? To act justly and to love mercy and to walk humbly with your God.
37:52 - Prayer: What does it mean to act justly today? (pause) Lord guide us in your Way of justice What does it mean to love mercy? (pause) Lord guide us in your Way of mercy. What does it mean to walk humbly with our God? (pause) Lord guide us in our journey with you. Deepen within us, faith, hope and love, in Jesus’ name. Amen.
39:15 - 40:33 - Reading: Matthew 5.1 – 12 NIVUK read by Kate Yates 5 Now when Jesus saw the crowds, he went up on a mountainside and sat down. His disciples came to him, 2 and he began to teach them. He said: 3 ‘Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. 4 Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted. 5 Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the earth. 6 Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be filled. 7 Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy. 8 Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God. 9 Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God. 10 Blessed are those who are persecuted because of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. 11 ‘Blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you and falsely say all kinds of evil against you because of me. 12 Rejoice and be glad, because great is your reward in heaven, for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who were before you.
40:50 - 43:32 - Hymn - R&S 636 The Church of Christ
43:37 - 55:38 - Address Reflecting on the meaning and use of the word "bless" and "blessings." The different ways in which the word can be used and the importance of matching words of blessings with actions of blessings. The experience of blessing a teddy bear at a hospice Many prophets remind us that blessings cannot be taken for granted and must be matched by actions of blessing. The importance of being blessings to others and not taking the blessings we enjoy for granted. Sharing food with leaders from other churches to mark the end of a week of prayer for Christian Unity. I pray that we will be a church that blesses our wider community that risks blessing unsuitable people and unsuitable things May we all know that glorious blessing of Jesus and be that blessing to our hurting world
55:59 - 01:00:54 - Hymn - MP 857 I, the Lord of sea and sky
01:01:00 - Prayers for the church and the world with the response So for them we pray Grant courage, peace and strength.
01:08:15 - 01:10:52 - Hymn - R&S 344 God of grace and God of glory
01:10:54 - 01:11:25 - Blessing
01:11:39 - 01:14:06 - Music, notices and photos

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 22nd January 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
08:26 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
10:22 - CALL TO WORSHIP Psalm 27:1 The lord is my light and my salvation; I will fear no one. The Lord will protect me from all danger; I will never be afraid.
11:23 - 13:18 - Hymn - R&S 608 – Awake, awake to love and work
13:26 - PRAYERS - Approach, Confession, Thanksgiving and Praise
18:31 - LORD'S PRAYER Modern version
19:09 - WE LISTEN FOR GOD’S WORD
19:59 - 21:48 - 1st READING Matthew 4:12-23 NIVUK read by David Bishop 12 When Jesus heard that John had been put in prison, he withdrew to Galilee. 13 Leaving Nazareth, he went and lived in Capernaum, which was by the lake in the area of Zebulun and Naphtali – 14 to fulfil what was said through the prophet Isaiah: 15 ‘Land of Zebulun and land of Naphtali, the Way of the Sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles – 16 the people living in darkness have seen a great light; on those living in the land of the shadow of death a light has dawned.’[a] 17 From that time on Jesus began to preach, ‘Repent, for the kingdom of heaven has come near.’ 18 As Jesus was walking beside the Sea of Galilee, he saw two brothers, Simon called Peter and his brother Andrew. They were casting a net into the lake, for they were fishermen. 19 ‘Come, follow me,’ Jesus said, ‘and I will send you out to fish for people.’ 20 At once they left their nets and followed him. 21 Going on from there, he saw two other brothers, James son of Zebedee and his brother John. They were in a boat with their father Zebedee, preparing their nets. Jesus called them, 22 and immediately they left the boat and their father and followed him. 23 Jesus went throughout Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, proclaiming the good news of the kingdom, and healing every disease and illness among the people.
22:00 - 27:32 - ALL AGE TALK ‘Are you called to follow?’ "Following" people on social media websites, and how the younger generation may interpret this differently than older generations. Can you identify these icons? Different social media websites use different terms for following people (e.g. followers on Twitter, subscribers on YouTube). Does following on social media cost you anything? The real cost of following someone on social media may be a mental one, contrast with Jesus asking someone to "follow me" in the Bible. If Jesus were on Twitter, it would be interesting to see how many tweets he would produce, and how many people would follow him. Social media today doesn't cost us anything in terms of money, but the cost may be more mental or emotional.
27:51 - 31:43 - HYMN R&S R&S 367 – I want to walk with Jesus Christ
32:14 - Introduction to the second reading
33:07 - 34:02 - 2nd READING Isaiah 9:1-4 NIVUK read by Valerie Bishop 2 The people walking in darkness have seen a great light; on those living in the land of deep darkness a light has dawned.
34:31 - 37:49 - HYMN R&S 679 – The Lord is my shepherd.
37:58 - 51:59 - SERMON ‘Leaders and followers’ The good, the bad, and the ugly of leadership styles. Tony Blair - "the art of leadership is being able to say no" Peter Drucker - "management is doing things right and leadership is doing the right things." An adapted definition of leadership given by Colin Powell, which is that the day the "congregation" stops bringing their problems to the leader is the day the leader has stopped leading, and either the congregation has lost confidence in the leader or they believe the leader doesn't care. Connect to the reading from Isaiah, which mentions Zebulun and Nephthali, two of the leaders of the twelve tribes The early part of the passage in Isaiah has a broader appeal and can be applied to anyone living in darkness and in the shadow of death. Linking the phrase "valley of the shadow of death" from the reading from Isaiah to the broader concept of living in darkness and difficulties. Applying this to anyone facing challenges and difficulties in life. Leadership in difficult times and the hope of light and guidance in those times.
WE MAKE OUR RESPONSE
52:19 - 54:30 - HYMN R&S 543 – Lead us, heavenly Father, lead us
54:35 - DEDICATION of our OFFERINGS
55:11 - PRAYERS of intercession
01:00:45 - 01:04:12 - HYMN R&S 509 – O Jesus, I have promised
01:04:41 - 01:04:58 - BLESSING
01:05:16 - 01:09:17 - Music, notices, and photos after the service
#Church #Worship #Sing #Organ #Faithful #Jesus #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Blessings #GoodNews #NIV #NIVUK #Bible #Lessons #King #GoodNews #Hymns #AllAreWelcome #JoinIn #Christian #WarmSpace #WednesdayCafe #RejoiceandSing

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 15th January 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
03:29 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
06:11 - Call to Worship – Poem by Dominic Windram
07:12 - 10:18 - Hymn - 187: Worship the Lord
10:28 - Opening Prayer – Faithfulness of God Almighty and loving God, we thank you for the assurance we have that you are always with us, that in you we will find help and strength in times of trouble, that whatever we face you will always be there to reach out and save us. Almighty and loving God. Take our faith, weak though it is. Kindle the sparks of life within us and fan a new flame of love within our hearts, so, may we set out into another week with renewed purpose, resolved to live and work for you, in the assurance that you are with us, now and always, Great is your faithfulness, from one generation to another. Thanks be to God. Amen.
Lord’s Prayer
12:12 - 14:38 - Hymn - 188: Born in the night
14:58 - 16:29 - Bible reading: Isaiah 60 Verses 1-6 read by Abigail Lokko
16:49 - 20:26 - Hymn - 183: Brightest and best
20:44 - 22:51 - Bible Reading: Matthew 2: 1-12 read by Harri Bello
23:27 - 25:50 - Epiphany Prayer of Confession Loving God, you guided the wise men to Bethlehem, offering a light for their path, and in faith they responded. Forgive us that all too often we fall short of their example. Gracious Lord, have mercy. You offer us guidance in innumerable ways – through the light of your word, the illumination of your Holy Spirit, the fellowship of your church, and the encounter of prayer, yet so often we either fail to hear or refuse to see. Gracious Lord, have mercy. We are too preoccupied with our own small affairs, eyes only for the immediate moment, our vision impeded by trivial concerns, so we fail to recognise where you are leading us, Gracious Lord, have mercy. We believe we know just where we are going, just what we want from life, and exactly how we can get it, and we resist any suggestion that we need to think again. Gracious Lord, have mercy. Loving God, forgive us our foolishness, our stubbornness, our weakness. Gracious Lord, have mercy. Forgive our pride, our lack of faith, our closed minds. Gracious Lord, have mercy. Forgive us for ignoring your guidance, for resting your will, and as a result so often walking in darkness. Gracious Lord, have mercy. Meet with us again we ask, and may the light of your love shine in our hearts, so that we cannot but see it or fail to respond in grateful praise and joyful service. Gracious Lord, have mercy, in the name of Christ .Amen
26:11 - 29:39 - Hymn - 185: Wise men seeking Jesus
29:46 - 45:14 - Talk: ‘What gifts shall we bring?’ - Pastor Vince Gerhardy The Wise Men are often depicted in Christmas imagery as arriving at the manger with the shepherds, but they may have arrived later, when Jesus was a child. The Wise Men are not named in the reading and little is known about their origins or how far they traveled. Gold, frankincense, and myrrh, unusual gifts for a baby. The story of the Wise Men is traditionally part of the celebration of Epiphany, which is usually celebrated on January 6th, 12 days after Christmas. Focusing on the Wise Men's story separately from the celebration of Jesus' birth allows us to appreciate their significance. The gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh are said to symbolize Jesus as a king, God and a sacrifice for humanity respectively. What gifts shall we bring to Jesus.
45:22 - 46:14 - Time of quiet reflection and silent prayers for the world ending with this prayer: Loving God, accept our gifts for your work today. Inspire our lives to reflect more truly the love of Jesus. Hear our silent prayers for people on our hearts and places in desperate need. Bring your healing and your peace, in Jesus name. Amen.
46:30 - 49:43 - Hymn 184: As with gladness men of old
49:45 - 50:03 - Blessing
51:10 - 52:43 - Organ voluntary
#Church #Worship #Sing #Organ #Faithful #Jesus #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Blessings #GoodNews #NIV #NIVUK #Bible #Lessons #King #GoodNews #Choir #AllAreWelcome #JoinIn #Epiphany #Christian #WarmSpace #WednesdayCafe
Speaking summaries provided using #ChatGPT

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 8th January 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
04:08 - Welcome and lighting of the peace candle
05:50 - CALL TO WORSHIP – Isaiah 42: 6-7
07:24 - Hymn - R&S 134 On Jordan’s bank the Baptist’s cry. (Tune 209)
10:07 - PRAYERS - Approach, Confession, Thanksgiving & Praise
14:30 - LORD'S PRAYER
15:10 - WE LISTEN FOR GOD’S WORD
15:51 - 17:36 - READING 1 – Isaiah 42:1-9 NIVUK read by Ian Bogart ‘Here is my servant, whom I uphold, my chosen one in whom I delight; I will put my Spirit on him, and he will bring justice to the nations. 2 He will not shout or cry out, or raise his voice in the streets. 3 A bruised reed he will not break, and a smouldering wick he will not snuff out.
In faithfulness he will bring forth justice; 4 he will not falter or be discouraged till he establishes justice on earth. In his teaching the islands will put their hope.’ 5 This is what God the LORD says – the Creator of the heavens, who stretches them out, who spreads out the earth with all that springs from it, who gives breath to its people, and life to those who walk on it: 6 ‘I, the LORD, have called you in righteousness; I will take hold of your hand. I will keep you and will make you to be a covenant for the people and a light for the Gentiles, 7 to open eyes that are blind, to free captives from prison and to release from the dungeon those who sit in darkness. 8 ‘I am the LORD; that is my name! I will not yield my glory to another or my praise to idols. 9 See, the former things have taken place, and new things I declare; before they spring into being I announce them to you.’
17:43 - 23:01 - ALL AGE TALK – Who is the servant? The identity of the "servant" in Isaiah 42. Initial understanding is that the servant is Jesus. Uncertainty about the true identity of the servant. The servant could be the nation of Israel. The servant could be Jacob, whose nickname was Israel. Isaiah wrote this passage before Jesus' birth.
24:29 - 25:28 - READING 2 – Matthew 3:13-17 NIVUK read by Lesley Bogart 13 Then Jesus came from Galilee to the Jordan to be baptised by John. 14 But John tried to deter him, saying, ‘I need to be baptised by you, and do you come to me?’ 15 Jesus replied, ‘Let it be so now; it is proper for us to do this to fulfil all righteousness.’ Then John consented. 16 As soon as Jesus was baptised, he went up out of the water. At that moment heaven was opened, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and alighting on him. 17 And a voice from heaven said, ‘This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased.’
26:42 - 30:36 - Hymn - R&S 195 I am the Lord of the dance
30:51 - 42:49 - SERMON – Baptism Similarities between statements in Isaiah and Matthew. Both passages begin with God declaring that the servant is his chosen one and in whom he delights or is well pleased. In Isaiah, the servant may be referring to the audience and others in a plural sense. The servant in Isaiah is described as humble and not war-like. Reflect on how they can embody this servant-like humility in their own lives. Both passages in Isaiah and Matthew launch mission for people. Isaiah 42:2 tells us that the servant will not shout or lift up their head. We should reflect on our own humility and how it relates to the servant in Isaiah.
43:03 - WE MAKE OUR RESPONSE
43:23 - 46:08 - Hymn - TP 13 Be still, for the presence of the Lord.
46:18 - DEDICATION of our OFFERINGS 47:18 - PRAYERS of intercession
WE GO OUT TO SERVE
52:04 - 55:13 - Hymn - R&S 187 Worship the Lord in the beauty of holiness.
55:16 - 55:35 - Blessing
56:24 - 57:58 - Organ voluntary

entry.title: New Year Worship (Audio Only) - Sunday 1st January 2023

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: New Year Worship (Audio Only) - Sunday 1st January 2023
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
06:45 - Call to worship Jesus said, A new commandment I give to you that you love one another as I have loved you. We bring our worship, seeking that love to share. Paul wrote, if anyone is in Christ, the new creation has come: the old has gone, the new is here! We bring our worship at the beginning of this new year. Not looking back, but always moving forwards: We bring our worship to you, the God of new life.
08:39 - Hymn - 159 Hark the herald angels sing
11:37 - Prayer of adoration and confession
13:42 - Introduction: What’s the time? Second Sunday of Christmas, 8th day of Christmas American Samoa and Western Samoa timezones Saint Jerome and his view on the relationship between Sunday and the "son of God" The symbolism of eight maids of milking being given as a gift.
20:00 - Lighting the Christmas Candle
22:10 - 24:02 - Reading: Ecclesiastes 3.1-13 NIVUK read by Kitty Bird 3 There is a time for everything, and a season for every activity under the heavens: 2 a time to be born and a time to die, a time to plant and a time to uproot, 3 a time to kill and a time to heal, a time to tear down and a time to build, 4 a time to weep and a time to laugh, a time to mourn and a time to dance, 5 a time to scatter stones and a time to gather them,
a time to embrace and a time to refrain from embracing, 6 a time to search and a time to give up, a time to keep and a time to throw away, 7 a time to tear and a time to mend, a time to be silent and a time to speak, 8 a time to love and a time to hate, a time for war and a time for peace.
27:28 - Hymn - 188 Born in the night, Mary’s child
26:35 - 28:43 - Reading: Revelation 21.1-6a NIVUK read by Rosemary Taylor 21 Then I saw ‘a new heaven and a new earth,’ for the first heaven and the first earth had passed away, and there was no longer any sea. 2 I saw the Holy City, the new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God, prepared as a bride beautifully dressed for her husband. 3 And I heard a loud voice from the throne saying, ‘Look! God’s dwelling-place is now among the people, and he will dwell with them. They will be his people, and God himself will be with them and be their God. 4 “He will wipe every tear from their eyes. There will be no more death” or mourning or crying or pain, for the old order of things has passed away.’ 5 He who was seated on the throne said, ‘I am making everything new!’ 6 He said to me: ‘It is done. I am the Alpha and the Omega, the Beginning and the End.
29:19 - 40:21 - Short Address: ‘God makes new’ How people have celebrated the start of the new year. A message from a daughter who chose to go to bed instead of celebrating the new year. The chaotic nature of recent years and the hope for a better 2023. People's attitudes towards time can vary based on their mood, age and circumstances. An inscription on an old clock at a Cathedral in Chester that speaks about how time slips away as a person ages. Ancient Greek language has two words for time, Chronos, which is chronological time and Kairos which is the special moments that stand out. Ecclesiastes, a philosopher, who talks about the flow and ebb of time and the choices one must make during different times. The choices one must make during different times
40:55 - Hymn - 685 vs 1 – 3 sung seated to begin our prayers
42:46 - 46:35 - Prayer for the world
47:08 - Prayer of Dedication at the beginning of this new year
47:50 - Communion: we invite you to share in the bread and wine at church (or at home) united in the name of Christ.
48:18 - Hymn - 63 Great God, we sing that mighty hand
51:10 - A Prayer of thanksgiving with the response We thank you Lord of life And praise your holy name
Lord’s Prayer
Closing Prayer
01:02:20 - Hymn 603 Lord for the years
01:06:01 - 01:06:34 - Blessing
01:07:04 - 01:09:14 - Organ voluntary

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Christmas Morning Worship - Sunday 25th December 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
17:15 - Welcome to our Christmas service
18:30 - 21:22 - Carol to prepare for worship: 155 While shepherds watched their flocks
21:25 - Welcome and introduction (including lighting of peace candle)
22:45 - Call to worship (words from Isaiah 9) A child is born to us! A son is given to us! And he will be our ruler; and will be called, Wonderful Counsellor, The Almighty, the Everlasting, Prince of peace. All: We come to worship Jesus Christ, born in Bethlehem, Light of the world, King of love and Lord of life.
23:30 - 27:19 - Hymn 160 - O come all ye faithful (omit verses 3 and 4)
27:20 - 29:54 - Part 1 Celebrating the Light
Lighting the Advent Candles We light each candle to remember those who played their part preparing the way for Jesus, Emmanuel, God with us; and we light the central candle to celebrate his birth and life and touch on our lives: All: Lord Jesus, light of the world, be with us in all our celebrations this day. Bring your love, hope and peace to our broken world, that all creation may learn the song of the angels: Glory to God in the highest and peace on earth. Amen.
30:24 - 31:05 - Song (tune Frere Jacques - unaccompanied) Christ our light, Christ our light, Light our lives, light our lives. We’ll be lights to others; we’ll be lights to others Light our lives, light our lives.
31:13 - Part 2: ‘opening the gift’
36:04 - 37:53 - Hymn 167 Once in Royal David’s city vs 1 and 2
37:56 - Part 3: Telling the story
42:06 - 43:58 - Hymn 167 Once in Royal David’s city vs 3 and 4
44:36 - 45:45 - Reading: John 1.1 – 5, 9 – 14 NIVUK read by Julia Sparks
45:54 - 48:39 - Part 4: Knowing the meaning
48:54 - 49:25 - Reading: ‘God came in person!’ read by Linda Curley
50:20 - 54:36 - Hymn 162 - In the bleak mid winter
54:43 - 58:27 - Part 5 - Praying for the world and ourselves Today we thank you, God of new life, for the child born in Bethlehem long ago, whose life continues to inspire and challenge and comfort us today. Help us to know his presence and share his peace… Lord of all life, hear our prayer. We pray for children born today and for their families, for midwives in their care; and we lift to you families where there is sadness or hurt... Lord of all life, hear our prayer. Today we pray for peace, peace in places where there is violence and war, anger and fear... Lord of all life, hear our prayer. We pray for travellers... those who have travelled home for Christmas, those travelling today, those seeking a new place to call home… Lord of all life, hear our prayer. We pray for all who are sick, and those who care for them – at home or in hospital. We remember those who have died, those we miss at the table and thank you, God of eternal life, for each of them in their uniqueness… Lord of all life, hear our prayer. And we pray for ourselves, for our needs, our hopes and fears, our joys and dreams for the future. Lead us Lord, in your way of generous love… Lord of all life, hear our prayer. God of new life, hear our prayers, spoken and silent, and unite us with all celebrating the birth of Jesus, as we pray the prayer he gave us: Lord’s Prayer
59:17 - 01:01:51 - Hymn 164 - Go tell it on the mountain
01:01:54 - 01:02:20 - Blessing Let us go in the peace and joy of Jesus Christ To share his love with all this Christmas Day And the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with us and all creation, now and always. Amen.
01:02:31 - 01:05:46 - Organ voluntary

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 18th December 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
10:14 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle 12:20 - Call to worship God of creation, God of history: God is here with us. God of mystery, God of blessing: God is here with us. God in Jesus, God named Emmanuel: God is here with us.
13:08 - 15:44 - Hymn - Joy to the world, the Lord is come (R&S 135)
15:52 - Opening Prayers and Lord’s Prayer
18:29 - 27:27 - Introduction: Nativity now – what part would you play? The recent Brownie sleepover on the nice warm floor Nativity - what part would you want? Shepherd, Mary, Joseph, and animal, an angel? An alien, a lobster? A snowman? What part would you play? A rat? The least significant but still with a part? Do we ever feel unloved? We are still welcomed by Jesus What part do we play in the Christmas story?
27:39 - 30:30 - Carol - The angel Gabriel (R&S 139)
30:43 - Lighting the Advent candles As we light the last candle before Christmas Day, we give thanks for the role Mary and Joseph played in God’s unfolding plan and pray: God of all our lives, you call each of us to play a part in your story and purposes for the world. As we give thanks for the courage and the humility of Mary and Joseph, may shine your light into the lives of others. Draw us all to the Christmas stable, where hope is born and all are loved, in Jesus’ name. Amen.
33:48 - 34:53 - Reading: Isaiah 7.10 – 16 GNB
36:13 - 39:21 - Song - Emmanuel, Emmanuel (MP 121) sung three times Emmanuel, Emmanuel, His name is called Emmanuel God with us, revealed in us – His name is called Emmanuel
40:01 - Find Mary…find Joseph (carols R&S 144 – 181)
44:55 - 46:24 - Matthew 1. 18 – 25 NIVUK
47:03 - 51:24 - Carol Joseph, son of David (Tune R&S 243 Noel nouvelet) 1. Joseph, son of David, son of Abraham; regally descended, son of tent and psalm; waited the day when, filled with joy and pride, he would marry Mary, she would be his bride.
2. Joseph, though a poor man, with no wealth or fame, yet possessed a treasure in his fam’ly name. He must pass on this honour to his son, in the line of David – then his job was done!
3. Yet, before the wedding, Mary was with child and there was no father; ev’ryone went wild! What could he do, to keep his name intact? Mary must be banished! Surely he must act!
4. Calmly, at God’s prompting, Joseph held his ground, risking, trusting, waiting; Mary still around. Somehow he knew, though how he could not tell, God would act through Jesus, all would then be well.
5. Showing such devotion, Joseph stood in line with ancestral women working God’s design: Rahab, and Tamar, Bathsheba and Ruth – each, when others faltered, stood for hope and truth.
6. Now the gift of Joseph – ancestry and name – graciously surrendered, nevermore the same; offered to Jesus, ’til God’s work is done, welcomes all the nations, seeks to make us one. © John Campbell (based on Matthew 1)
52:14 - Short prayer
52:32 - 01:03:42 - Short Talk Gathering this afternoon for the carol service Keeping quiet about the score for the #WorldCupFinal Focus on Emmanuel, Christ the light of the world Other people playing their part around Jesus Looking at Mary and Joseph Mary does play a part in our carols but just Silent Night with Mary and Joseph looking on protectively Joseph was older, not unusual at that time Their son was unusual Revealing God's immense, eternal love Mary carried Jesus, Joseph protects them and takes them to Bethlehem to be registered Telling the story of the birth One word to take home - Emmanuel - God with us
01:03:54 - 01:06:09 - Song - Born in the night, Mary’s child (R&S 188) sung seated
01:06:15 - Prayers for each other and the world
01:12:22 - 01:17:16 - Carol - See! In yonder manger low (R&S 157)
01:17: 16 - 01:17:46 - Blessing
01:18:15 - 01:20:05 - Music, notices and photos
#Church #Worship #Advent #AllAreWelcome #URC #UnitedReformedChurch #Hope #Isaiah #FourCandles #ForkHandles #Matthew #AllAreWelcome #URC #unitedreformedchurch

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday 11th December 2022
media:group.media:description:
00:00:00 - Opening music, photos, and notices
07:35 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (Linda as duty elder)
08:32 - Introduction – Linda
09:50 - 13:40 - Carol: In the Bleak Mid-Winter (R&S 162)
13:46 - Story Telling – Julia What are you looking forward to most about Christmas Dinner Cousins Grandchildren Now think back to when you were a child? Presents Stocking Which do you like best - giving or receiving Why do we give presents? Enjoyment, showing our love for one another, reminding us of the first Christmas present wrapped in strips of cloth Jesus was the first and best Remembering our friends, family and God at Christmas We need to receive, unwrap, thank, enjoy, and share our presents and God's present of Jesus
17:47 - 19:00 - Reading: Luke 2. 4-12 (NIVUK) – Samuel 4 So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David. 5 He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child. 6 While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born, 7 and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them. 8 And there were shepherds living out in the fields near by, keeping watch over their flocks at night. 9 An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. 10 But the angel said to them, ‘Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. 11 Today in the town of David a Saviour has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. 12 This will be a sign to you: you will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.’
19:14 - 23:17 - Carol - We Three Kings of Orient Are
23:33 - 24:37 - Reading: Matthew 2. 1-2, 9-12 (NIVUK) After Jesus was born in Bethlehem in Judea, during the time of King Herod, Magi from the east came to Jerusalem 2 and asked, ‘Where is the one who has been born king of the Jews? We saw his star when it rose and have come to worship him.’ 9 After they had heard the king, they went on their way, and the star they had seen when it rose went ahead of them until it stopped over the place where the child was. 10 When they saw the star, they were overjoyed. 11 On coming to the house, they saw the child with his mother Mary, and they bowed down and worshipped him. Then they opened their treasures and presented him with gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh. 12 And having been warned in a dream not to go back to Herod, they returned to their country by another route.
